prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We select three CO line emissions of 12CO, 13CO, and C18O. These lines can trace a different density in the disk. Since our purposes are investigating gas dissipation in the cavity of transitional disks, different-density tracers are necessary.
Because the typical line width in protoplanatary disks is a few to several km/s, our requested spectral resolution of about 0.2 km/s is reasonble values. To keep information of the gas kinematics, we do not request spectral averaging.

We need to spatially resolve the cavity in transitional disks. Our selected transitional disks have large cavities of r>0.''15; thus, our requested spational resolution of 0.$''$2 will clearly resolve the cavities in our samples.
Since the size of cavities in our samples is 1'' at most, LAS of 2'' is resonable.

We propose to observe 15 transitional disk systems. To obtain uniform data set, we determine the sensitivity based on the faintest object Sz91 in our samples. Thus, our estimate would result in a lower limit of a SN ratio in our samples.
According to cycle 0 observations of Sz91 with a spatial resolution of 0.''8x0.''6 (Canovas+15), peak continuum and line flux densities and 4mJy/beam and 0.8Jy km/s/beam, respectively. Thus, expected these flux densities in our observations at a spatial resolution of 0.$''$2 are 0.31mJy/beam and 62mJy km/s/beam, respectively. In the requested observations, the achieved SN ratios in dust continuum and line emissions are 10, which would be sufficient to achieve our science goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It is widely believed that protoplanetary disks dissipate inside-out. In particular, as an intermediate phase from gas-rich primordial disks to gas-poor debris disks, transitional disks that have a cavity in the central region of the disk could be ideal testbeds to catch gas dissipation in progress within their cavities. Here we propose band 6 (1.3 mm) observations of fifteen transitional disk systems with a relatively large (r >0.''15) cavity in dust continuum, especially focusing on CO line emissions (12CO, 13CO and C18O) at a spatial resolution of 0.''2 to estimate the amount of the gas in the cavity of dust continuum. Our goal is to obtain observational evidence of gas-dissipation in progress among transitional disk systems. To determine to what extent the gas is still contained in the cavity, we measure the `depletion facor' of the CO gas, i.e., the flux ratio of the-gas-outside-the-cavity to inside-the-cavity. Systematic and quantitative comparisons of the gas in the cavity will enable to help our understanding of the disk evolution in transitional disk systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrobiology Center. National Institutes of Natural Sciences.

Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Oklahoma, University of
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Division of Liberal Arts, Kogakuin University
Extra-Solar Planet Detection Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
